body:
### Problem

I imported the project into visual studio 2022 (arm64 version) and it compiles just fine, but with target x86. Probably I need to modify CMake files to target arm64, but I am not a developer so no idea how to do that.

### Expected behavior

Please provide some more instruction for compiling on arm on windows.

comment_data.body: Just to be clear, cross compilation is not supported. To build for ARM, you need to build _on_ ARM.
I am on arm
Can I get some actual details? What error mesaage are you getting?
Nothing goes wrong, it just cross compiles to x86. Instead of compiling to arm64. I am guessing that is the default for cmake projects, but I don't know.
VS has a menu with options to choose a target.

It doesn't allow choosing an arm target. If I create a new desktop app project I can set target to be arm64. If I create a new cmake project this is not allowed, so it might be  a current limitation of cmake + visual studio.

I also tried to compile form command line, I can do it with gcc but that gives the wrong target, I don't know how to force arm64 and also it appears gcc currently does not support windows arm64 target. So clang might be the way to go, but how?

I manually added the following CMake preset:
Mind you I don't know if this is correct. 

{
  "name": "arm",
  "displayName": "arm",
  "inherits": "base",
  "architecture": {
    "value": "arm64",
    "strategy": "external"
  },
  "cacheVariables": {
    "CMAKE_BUILD_TYPE": "Release"
  }
WIth this the compilation starts, but fails midway.

Severity	Code	Description	Project	File	Line	Suppression State	Details
Error		CMake Error at C:/Program Files/Microsoft Visual Studio/2022/Community/Common7/IDE/CommonExtensions/Microsoft/CMake/CMake/share/cmake-3.28/Modules/FindPackageHandleStandardArgs.cmake:230 (message):
  Could NOT find Luv (missing: LUV_LIBRARY LUV_INCLUDE_DIR) (Required is at
  least version "1.43.0")		C:/Program Files/Microsoft Visual Studio/2022/Community/Common7/IDE/CommonExtensions/Microsoft/CMake/CMake/share/cmake-3.28/Modules/FindPackageHandleStandardArgs.cmake	230

Is there any guide to guide us to build nvim on win on arm?

The current documentation doesn't work for me.

If necessary I can provide any errors I encounter.
I think there might a luajit bug that prevents buikding it on windows arm. Need confirmation though.
Hi @dundargoc , will windows on arm be officially supported at some point in the future? Github seems to be offering arm versions of Windows, Linux pipelines this year.
Not on the free tier. Until that happens, the answer remains No.

> Hi @dundargoc , will windows on arm be officially supported at some point in the future? 

Let's fix this problem before worrying about that. Can you build luajit on arm windows by following their buils instructions? If you get the same error therenit might be worth creating a bug report for them.
Maybe someone on the neovim team can just rent a snapdragon X elite machine from amazon. They have a free 'rental' for up to 40 days. Enough to profile the issue with building.

> Let's fix this problem before worrying about that. Can you build luajit on arm windows by following their buils instructions? If you get the same error therenit might be worth creating a bug report for them.

When I switch to build with CMD, I'm also getting an error when building gettext.

The error is the same as you

I just got a new Windows on ARM device and I will share my experiences for the maintainers' reference.

1. ✅ The x64 build of Neovim works on its own, ❌ but the compiled treesitter parsers don't

   I tried both `clang` and `zig` as the compiler, `:checkhealth` shows that all parsers failed with `uv_dlopen: no error`.
   https://github.com/nvim-treesitter/nvim-treesitter/issues/6764
   This issue suggests that a similar problem also happens on ARM-powered Macs. A comment said that by using a native terminal with Rosetta 2 disabled, the error went away.

1. ✅ Compiling Neovim to ARM64 with LLVM MinGW

   I used this https://github.com/mstorsjo/llvm-mingw toolchain and got the missing GNU utils from vcpkg. For the two executables in gettext I just grabbed them from the Internet.
   <details>
   <summary>Here's the build command I use If someone wants to follow:</summary>

       cmake -S cmake.deps -B .deps -G Ninja --preset ci -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release
       cmake --build .deps
       cmake -B build -G Ninja --preset release `
         --toolchain D:\vcpkg\scripts\buildsystems\vcpkg.cmake `
         -DICONV_INCLUDE_DIR="D:\vcpkg\installed\arm64-mingw-static\include" `
         -DICONV_LIBRARY="D:\vcpkg\installed\arm64-mingw-static\lib\libiconv.a" `
         -DGETTEXT_MSGMERGE_EXECUTABLE="D:\gettext0.21-iconv1.16-static-64\bin\msgmerge.exe" `
         -DGETTEXT_MSGFMT_EXECUTABLE="D:\gettext0.21-iconv1.16-static-64\bin\msgfmt.exe" `
         -DLIBINTL_INCLUDE_DIR="D:\vcpkg\installed\arm64-mingw-static\include" `
         -DLIBINTL_LIBRARY="D:\vcpkg\installed\arm64-mingw-static\lib\libintl.a" `
         -DCMAKE_INSTALL_PREFIX="<install-location>"
       cmake --build build --target install

   </details>

   Using it is generally fine but for some reason `:checkhealth` doesn't work:

   <details>
   <summary>Error</summary>

       ==============================================================================
       .: require("..health").check()

       - ERROR Failed to run healthcheck for "." plugin. Exception:
         [string "require("..health").check()"]:1: module '..health' not found:
         	no field package.preload['..health']
         cache_loader: module ..health not found
         cache_loader_lib: module ..health not found
         ......

       E5009: Invalid 'runtimepath'
       Error executing lua: Vim:E117: Unknown function: health#C:\Users\<username>\AppData\Local\nvim-data\lazy\telescope.nvim\autoload\health\telescope#check
       stack traceback:
              [C]: in function 'call'
              ...s\<username>\Neovim\share\nvim\runtime/lua/vim/health.lua:366: in function '_check'
              [string "<nvim>"]:1: in main chunk 

   </details>

   It seems like the word _nvim_ just becomes _._, so `require("nvim.health")` becomes `require("..health")` and Lua doesn't know where to find it.
   I am a Neovim beginner and don't know what's wrong here. Maybe an experienced user could shed some light.

1. ❌ Compiling Neovim to ARM64 with MSVC

   Following `BUILD.md`, the build failed at step `gettext` when building dependencies:

   <details>
   <summary>Log</summary>

       > cmake --build .deps --config Release
       MSBuild version 17.10.4+10fbfbf2e for .NET Framework

         Performing build step for 'gettext'
         MSBuild version 17.10.4+10fbfbf2e for .NET Framework

           libgettextsrc.vcxproj -> D:\neovim\.deps\build\src\gettext-build\Release\libgettextsr

       cl : command line warning D9025: overriding '/W1' with '/w' [D:\neovim\.deps\build\src\ge

       C:\Program Files\Microsoft Visual Studio\2022\Community\VC\Tools\MSVC\14.40.33807\include

       86d92baa99d49f8c77578d9442502848\gettext-build.rule;D:\neovim\.deps\CMakeFiles\86d92baa99
       d49f8c77578d9442502848\gettext-install.rule;D:\neovim\.deps\CMakeFiles\00d2257b6d3eb40482
       2e2231f22c703c\gettext-complete.rule;D:\neovim\.deps\CMakeFiles\56ffd030cbb2c334300b5fad1
       84740d1\gettext.rule' exited with code 1. [D:\neovim\.deps\gettext.vcxproj]

   Noted that Luajit can be compiled without issue, the problem could be that MSVC does not play well with GNU libraries.

---

@dundargoc ICYMI. I am sorry if this bothers you.
(nvim-treesitter issues are out of scope here. as long as the _bundled_ parsers work, that's all we care about here. but, yes, you need to compile parsers for the same architecture as nvim.)
@atlanswer Hi, Can you talk about the entire build process and preconditions? Thank you very much!

> @atlanswer Hi, Can you talk about the entire build process and preconditions? Thank you very much!

It depends which compiler you want to use. To use MSVC you can proceed as follows:

Open arm 64 native tools command prompt (search in Start). (Afterwards, you might want to execute pwsh or nu if you prefer those shells.)

Execute the building commands as described in the instructions: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/BUILD.md

> > @atlanswer Hi, Can you talk about the entire build process and preconditions? Thank you very much!
> 
> It depends which compiler you want to use. To use MSVC you can proceed as follows:
> 
> Open arm 64 native tools command prompt (search in Start). (Afterwards, you might want to execute pwsh or nu if you prefer those shells.)
> 
> Execute the building commands as described in the instructions: https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/BUILD.md

Thanks, I did that. You can see my reply above.  What I'd like to know is the approach of @atlanswer  in this thread who said he had successfully built nvim.

Or share the product of the build. 😂

> @atlanswer Hi, Can you talk about the entire build process and preconditions? Thank you very much!

Do you mean compiling with MinGW?

The process is generally the same. You _don't_ open the VS shell and add MinGW tools to Path.
The toolchain and commands are already documented above. Use `vcpkg install <pkg_name> --triplet=arm64-windows-static` for the missing GNU packages. I used the gettext executables from here (https://mlocati.github.io/articles/gettext-iconv-windows.html).

For ones who try building nvim this way, please share if you encounter the `:checkhealth` issue. It seems like the only missing pieces for now.

labels.description: building and installing Neovim using the provided scripts
labels.name: build

title: building on ARM on Windows fails on gettext
